Agreeing with Jim is a standard responsearound here (as it should 
be). I have a tsuba that confirms one of his points exactly- a late 
muromachi/momoyama tosho plate that got dressed up later w/ a gold 
mimi and gold and shakudo mons- it did paper at a previous shinsa 
(72 pts) to "Mid-Edo Shoami".  Had the soft-metal work not been of 
very good quality it certainly would have scored lower and I can 
only guess at what it would have done had the plate been unaltered.
Cheers,
Kirk

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...> 
wrote:
> Milt and Rich,
> Later inlay is a case by case judgment.  Because the originality 
of the tsuba is compromised, there will usually be a significant 
point reduction for later inlay to a good, older iron plate.  If the 
inlay is extensive it will probably fail.   If it is an attempt 
to "convert" the tsuba to a different type (even if mumei), or is 
very crude or done after the Edo period, it will fail.
> 
> A hypothetical good Muromachi period Tosho guard with a subtle mon 
inlaid during the Edo period would probably pass, but with a much 
lower point level that the unaltered plate would have been awarded.  
Also, if there is significant alteration to the piece, the date 
given will be that of the latest work.
> 
> Most of the late gomoku zogan, mukade, etc., will fail for poor 
quality.  Maybe an exceptional example could pass, but I can't think 
of any examples.  Does anyone have one of these guards with an 
origami? 
> 
> My observations only, not endorsed by anyone.
> Jim
> 
>   > Jim,
>   >  While making copies for the Chicago shinsa,I notice an iron 
tsuba 
>   > got the pinkie ........reason given was the inlays were added 
later.
>   > Why is that ?  I mean if the soft metal inlays were added in 
the Edo 
>   > days, it was " fashionable " then and not meant to deceive .
>   > I recall that tsuba was a mumei.
>   > 
> 
>   Very interested in the reply here. Seems to me a lot of
>   very good tsuba had inlay which were later applications.
>   Ko-Nara, Heianjo, etc commonly used Saotome tsuba as
>   starting points. Also most of the gomoku zogan and mukade
>   styles, the inlay or wire is a later addition. I'm sure
>   many other examples could be cited. Does that
>   mean none of those are eligible for papers?
> 
>   Rich S
> 
>
